The kids are alright

15 Nov 2008

I recently read Carl Honoré’s Under Pressure: Rescuing Childhood from the Culture of Hyper-Parenting. This book signals the arrival of what I see as a new trend. For years, parents have been bombarded with toys and props designed to make our children, from infancy,  smarter and more stimulated. Prompted by the incredible success of Baby Einstein, companies like Fisher Price jumped on the bandwagon, with sub-brands like “Play and Learn,” “Laugh and Learn.” The operative word always being *learn. *I see something new on the horizon, and it looks alot like something old.

This year’s Parenting Magazines’ Toy Trends 2008 lists Eco Toys as the #1 trend. The #5 trend is “Back to Basics” toys described as:

“from straight-from-the-woodshop block sets by Tree Blocks (so natural, some still have bark), to Front Porch Classic’s wooden Classic Magic 8 Ball, wooden toys have simple, sturdy, just-like-I-used-to-have appeal.”

The Baby Einstein backlash is nothing new (did anyone really think those movies made kids smarter???), research has long indicated that none of these brand promises result in brainier babies. What is new is a viable alternative. The slow food, green and local movements (not to mention lead-tainted toys from China)  have created a new zeitgeist that promises a new approach to kids’ entertainment. And not a moment too soon.

A front runner in this trend is Oompa Toys. With a tag-line reading: “No batteries. No blinking lights. No cartoon-themed toys. Period” they have a solid focus and clear, honest communications. Not to mention fantastic toys. They’ve just opened their first store in Wisconsin. If I’ve got this right, it’ll be the first of many.

About us

Hypenotic is a marketing strategy, design & development firm that chooses to use its powers for good. We’re a certified founding member of B Corp in Canada, and if you don’t know what that is, it’s time you do. Since ’98, we’ve helped a lot of interesting people do important things. We create relevant communications and useful experiences. Find out more.
